bioghist.p: Edwin H. (Ned) Colbert (1905-2001) was a noted paleontologist. He spent 40 years as the curator of fossil reptiles and amphibians at the American Museum of Natural History in New York. Upon retirement, he and his wife moved to Flagstaff, Arizona, where he was named honorary curator of vertebrate paleontology at the Museum of Northern Arizona. During his career, he published more than 425 scientific publications, including 17 books. From 1937 to 1941, Colbert commuted from New York to Philadelphia, spending a day each week working in the paleontology collections of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia. During this period, he also participated in the Academy expedition to Nebraska in 1938, and lectured at Bryn Mawr College.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of an annotated photocopy of a typescript of A Catalogue of Fossil Vertebrate Types in the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, by Edwin H. Colbert and Mary Youngman Ayer, Part III Mammalia, 274 pages.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
